conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the suitcase and use the given conditions to find the coefficient of friction \(\mu\) and the angle \(\theta\).
The image shows a suitcase which can be either pushed or pulled on the ground.
The total mass of the suitcase is 15 kg, and the gravitational acceleration is 10 m/s².
The resistance of the suitcase to the ground is proportional to the supporting force of the ground, the ratio is \(\mu\).
The minimum value of the pull is 90 N, and the angle between the pull and the horizontal direction is \(\theta\).

premise: Weight (\(W\)) is calculated using \(W = mg\), where \(m = 15 \text{ kg}\) and \(g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2\).
conclusion: The weight of the suitcase is 150 N.
The pulling force is given as \(F = 90 \text{ N}\) and it makes an angle \(\theta\) with the horizontal.
Normal force (\(N\)) is the force exerted by the ground on the suitcase, perpendicular to the surface.
Frictional force (\(f\)) is given by \(f = \mu N\), where \(\mu\) is the coefficient of friction.

premise: The pulling force \(F\) can be resolved into two components: Horizontal component: \(F \cos \theta\), Vertical component: \(F \sin \theta\).
conclusion: The components of the pulling force are \(F \cos \theta\) and \(F \sin \theta\).

premise: For the suitcase to move uniformly, the net force in the vertical direction must be zero: \(N + F \sin \theta = W\).
For the suitcase to move uniformly, the net force in the horizontal direction must also be zero: \(F \cos \theta - f = 0\).
conclusion: The equation for horizontal force is \(F \cos \theta = \mu (150 - 90 \sin \theta)\).
